title: Taxonomical composition
section: 4 Did we find bacteria from human excretions?
text:
4 Did we find bacteria from human excretions?
Yes! All bacterial species in Table 1 were detected in the monitoring and are also documented to come from the human gastrointestinal track or other bodily fluids. The most well-known of which is Escherichia coli, although there are many more species of bacteria living inside our bodies.



Table 1: Species of present bacteria with a known human origin.

4.2 Are there compositional differences between samples?

title: Citometry
text: Cytometry enable us to quantitatively measure cell concentration based on parameters like cell size, color, morphology and DNA content. This technology was developed in the field of human medicine and is now applied to marine sciences for microplankton counting and characterization. In this project, we classified cell types in three groups:

title: Citometry
section: 1 How much of each microplankton group was there?
text:
1 How much of each microplankton group was there?








Figure 1: Density functions for all microplankton groups measured. Horizontal axis in logarithmic scale.













Figure 2: Median microplanktonic concentrations with min-max ranges across seasons. Vertical axis in logarithmic scale.

title: Citometry
section: 2 Which were the differences between sampling stations?
text:
2 Which were the differences between sampling stations?

Peña la Vieja is once again brought to our attention in Figure 5. We registered a minimum for both genuses of cyanobacteria. The relative lower cell concentration in El Confital compared to Las Canteras is also evident, specially so for Synechoccocus.
The same pattern observed previously in cyanobacteria and eukaryotes repeats when DNA content is considered. Figure 6 illustrates Peña la Vieja as having a relatively lower cell concentration. The gap between Las Canteras and El Confital is also present, with El Confital at relative lower values. Within El COnfital, however, El Confital 2 is significantly lower than El Confital 1.








Figure 3: Organic nutrient distribution across sampling stations. Horizontal axis in logarithmic scale.













Figure 4: Box plots of eukaryotic cells distribution across measuring stations. Vertical axis in logarithmic scale.













Figure 5: Box plots of cyanobacteria distribution across measuring stations. Vertical axis in logarithmic scale.













Figure 6: Box plots of DNA content distribution across measuring stations. Vertical axis in logarithmic scale.

title: Citometry
section: 3 How did microplankton concentration vary over time?
text:
3 How did microplankton concentration vary over time?
Figure 7 shows minimum eukaryotic cell count during the spring 2022. Also worth remarking, values tend to decrease between January 2022 and October 2022 for both size scales.
The decreasing tendency mentioned before is not symmetrical between nano and pico scales. As observed in Figure 8, picoeukaryotes concentration is stable after summer 2022 whereas nanoeukaryotic cell count increased drastically in autumn 2022.
In Figure 9 we observe the minimum at Peña la Vieja during late winter 2022. At El Confital 1, Synechoccocus count fell to a minimum while Prochlorococcus remained at middle values.
Figure 10 shows a decoupling between the otherwise highly correlated concentrations of both genuses.
When seasonal variation is considered (Figure 11), we registered minimum values in spring 2022 for HNA. Contrarily, the minimum for LNA happened before, in autumn 2022. This inverse correlation between HNA and LNA can be better observed in Figure 12. There is an evident opposing tendency between HNA and LNA cells due to their reproductive strategies. It has been proposed by Santos et al. (2019) that HNA bacteria flourish during fecal contamination events. This could be the case at hand during summer 2022, when we observed maximum values for HNA.








Figure 7: Eukaryotic cells temporal distribution. Vertical axis in logarithmic scale.













Figure 8: Box plots of eukaryotic cells seasonal distribution. Vertical axis in logarithmic scale.













Figure 9: Cyanobacteria temporal distribution. Vertical axis in logarithmic scale.













Figure 10: Box plots of cyanobacteria seasonal distribution. Vertical axis in logarithmic scale.













Figure 11: DNA content temporal distribution. Vertical axis in logarithmic scale.













Figure 12: Box plots of DNA content seasonal distribution. Vertical axis in logarithmic scale.

title: Environmental nutrients
text: The environmental availability of certain nutrients on which microbes depend can deeply shape the composition of the microbiome. Chemically speaking, nutrients are very diverse in molecular weight, composition and complexity. In this project we will classify them into two main groups:

title: Environmental nutrients
section: 1 Did different nutrients have similar concentrations?
text:
1 Did different nutrients have similar concentrations?
By observing overall distribution in Figure 1, we can pinpoint an evident difference between organic and inorganic nutrients. That is, organic nutrients concentration ranges are two to three orders of magnitude higher—TOC close to 100 μM, and TON around 10 μM. This proportion is representative of the Redfield (1933) ratio, which quantifies elemental concentrations of marine organic matter according to the proportion \(C:N:P = 106:16:1\). This proportion is highly representative of our data.








Figure 1: Density functions for all nutrient chemical formulas measured. Horizontal axis in logarithmic scale.













Figure 2: Median nutrient concentrations with min-max ranges across seasons. Vertical axis in logarithmic scale.

title: Environmental nutrients
section: 2 Were there differences between sampling stations?
text:
2 Were there differences between sampling stations?
Observing Figure 3, it is clear at first glance that TOC concentration across the coast is more homogeneous than that of TON. The TOC maximum of Peña la Vieja also stands out. Moving to figure Figure 5 we observe that it was measured at the end of the monitoring period in the spring of 2023. On the other hand, TON dropped in El Confital 1 and Peña la Vieja between October 2022 and April 2023. This is not the case at Hotel Cristina. Further investigation is needed in order to understand the factors driving these processes.
In both Figure 4 and Figure 6, we can observe a difference between El Confital and Las Canteras. Concretely, Si(OH)₄ and NO₃⁻ + NO₂⁻ concentration are overall higher in Las Canteras compared to El Confital. Within Las Canteras, these nutrients show a decreasing tendency as we move North. This pattern is representative of different land input regimes, whose shaping agents are the ravines located South of Las Canteras. Ravine discharge contains siliceous sediments from volcanic rocks as well as nitrtates. However, in Figure 4 shows an unusual distribution of NO₃⁻ + NO₂⁻ at Peña la Vieja, which could be an indicator of anthropogenic input of nutrients.








Figure 3: Organic nutrient distribution across sampling stations. Horizontal axis in logarithmic scale.













Figure 4: Inorganic nutrient distribution across sampling stations. Horizontal axis in logarithmic scale.

title: Environmental nutrients
section: 3 How did nutrient concentration change over time?
text:
3 How did nutrient concentration change over time?








Figure 5: Organic nutrient temporal distribution. Vertical axis in logarithmic scale.













Figure 6: Inorganic nutrient temporal distribution. Vertical axis in logarithmic scale.

title: Welcome!
text:
Las Canteras beach in Las Palmas de Gran Canaria. Foto by Bengt Nyman.
Welcome to the Canteras Microbiome Project! A research project of marine microbial indicators of biological contamination in Las Palmas de Gran Canaria, Spain. This project is made in association with Biological Oceanography in a Changing Ocean - IOCAG and their team from the University of Las Palmas de Gran Canaria.
The database of the project was made possible by Markel Gómez Letona1, Maria Fernanda Montero2 and Javier Arístegui3.

title: Welcome!
section: 1 The monitoring program
text:
1 The monitoring program
The microbiome monitoring consists of 47 samples. As shown in Figure 1, these were collected in five different locations across Las Canteras and El Confital. The monitoring period spanned for 2 years, it began in July 2021 and ended in April 2023, with a sampling frequency of around 1 month.








Figure 1: Map of Las Palmas de Gran Canaria showing sampling locations.

title: Welcome!
section: Footnotes

title: Sea Surface Temperature
text: When it comes to environmental variables, temperature is often one of the most defining of environmental conditions, and also, one of the easiest to measure. Understanding sea surface temperature (SST) distribution across of monitoring program can help us understand natural fluctuations in the microbiome composition due to seasonal changes in the water.

title: Sea Surface Temperature
section: 1 How did temperature vary over the year?
text:
1 How did temperature vary over the year?
When we think about changes in seawater temperature over time, we tend to relate high temperatures with summer time. Although we mostly enjoy bathing at the beach in summer —June, July and August—, there’s a common misconception about seasonal SST variation in assuming that higher temperatures at sea occur simultaneously with atmospheric temperatures. This is not exactly the case. As you can observe in Figure 1, lowest annual SST is recorded in March, which also marks the arrival of the spring. The highest temperature, on the contrary, is measured in October, for us commonly associated with the beginning of the autumn.








Figure 1: Sea surface temperature variations across the year.

title: Sea Surface Temperature
section: 2 Was there any difference between sampling stations?
text:
2 Was there any difference between sampling stations?
Although we generally understand the sea surface as mostly homogeneous in temperature at a local scale, morphological and bathymetrical factors can possibly create spatial differences in distributions. Las Canteras beach is partially closed to the open sea by a morphological feature known as la Barra [the Barrier]. However, as shown in Figure 2, this doesn’t seem to be the case from an overview perspective. It’s important to note that la Barra is significantly eroded, and open surface waters can reach the closed water mass daily at high tide.








Figure 2: Sea surface temperature distribution across monitoring stations.

title: Amplicon Sequence Variants
text: Target genome region during polymerase chain reaction (PCR) divides the data into two major communities. These regions of rRNA are 16S and 18S, which correspond to prokaryotic and eukaryotic ribosomes, respectively. Each sequence produces an amplicon sequence variants (ASVs), which represent the fundamental observational units of our database. An ASV normally can be mapped to an individual known taxa —we will explore taxonomic diversity in [Community Composition][community-composition.qmd]—. But it can also happens that some sequences do not correspond to any known taxa.

title: Amplicon Sequence Variants
section: 1 Are all taxa equally common?
text:
1 Are all taxa equally common?
Encounters refer to the number of samples in which a taxon was found. This count ranges between 47 encounters —the maximum number of samples— and 1. Encounters are indicative of taxon rarity, ASVs encountered many times are considered common while those encountered a few times are considered uncommon. We can easily calculate de probability of encountering each ASV by diving the number of encounters by the total number of repetitions. To further facilitate the analysis of ASV rate, it was arbitrarily decided to bin the probabilities into 4 equally spaced ranges of 25 %. These ranges of rate are 0–25 %, 25–50 %, 50–75 % and 75–100 %.








Figure 1: Number of amplicon sequence variants by their encounter count. Vertical axis in logarithmic scale.













Figure 2: Number of amplicon sequence variants in each rate range. Vertical axis in logarithmic scale.

title: Amplicon Sequence Variants
section: 2 Are ASVs equally abundant?
text:
2 Are ASVs equally abundant?
The number of reads each taxon has is directly related to its abundance within each particular sample. Relative abundance is preferred over reads because not all samples contained the same number of total ASV reads (Figure 3). This inconsistency can be misleading when comparing data from different samples Gloor et al. (2017). Relative abundance is easily computed by dividing the number of reads of a certain taxon by the total ASV reads within the sample. Figure 5 shows that, overall, rarer taxa are less abundant. Note that, as stated above, there are far more data points in singular and recurring categories than in the ubiquitous category. Longer right tails in infrequent ASV distribution indicate exceptional cases where rare taxa become predominant in the sample. Samples dominated by rare taxa indicate a community response driven by environmental changes.








Figure 3: Bar plot of total number of reads for each rate category.













Figure 4: Violin plot showing the distribution of taxon relative abundance by rate. All data points are represented, with close to 10⁵ observations.













Figure 5: Density function distribution of amplicon sequence variants relative abundance by encounter rate. All data points are represented, with close to 10⁵ observations. Horizontal axis in logarithmic scale.

title: Amplicon Sequence Variants
section: 3 How does ecological diversity vary over time?
text:
3 How does ecological diversity vary over time?
Community diversity is an indicator of overall microbiome health and fitness. Therefore, relative low Shannon Index values signal community degrading processes, including wastewater intrusion. Figure 7 point again to our suspicion that the summer 2022 was affected by contamination.








Figure 6: Box plots of Shannon diversity index spatial distribution













Figure 7: Box plots of Shannon diversity index seasonal distribution.

title: Enterococci
text: Enterococcus is a genus of bacteria widely used as an indicator of fecal contamination. Standard biochemical tests and culturing methods are used to establish the amount of colony forming units (CFU) for an amount of sampled volume of water. Public regulations define threshold values for enterococci concentration to assets water quality, and many bathing zones are closed because they don’t meet hygienic criteria. In a review study, Peter, Bertone, and Stewart (2025) claimed that sewage discharge from human and animal wastewaters is the primary source of enterococci. They also proposed heavy rainfall and storms as key drivers of acute contamination events in coastal waters.

title: Enterococci
section: 1 When did the contamiantion events happened in El Confital?
text:
1 When did the contamiantion events happened in El Confital?
As observed in figure Figure 1, 2022 was a year of noticeable contamination events.








Figure 1: Temporal evolution of enterococci colony forming units in El Confital.

title: Enterococci
section: 2 How does this data overlap with our mcirobiome samples?
text:
2 How does this data overlap with our mcirobiome samples?
Figure 2 shows which samples are more likely affected by fecal contamination events.








Figure 2: Overlay of contamination events with microbiome sample collection.
